question: What is the genus and species of the bear in which the Florida black bear is a subspecies of?

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about the Florida black bear, including its subspecies classification.
Extract the genus and species of the bear in which the Florida black bear is classified as a subspecies.

graph.explanation: The graph consists of two main nodes. The first node retrieves information specifically about the Florida black bear, focusing on its taxonomic classification and subspecies data. The second node uses this classification information to determine the genus and species of the typical bear of which the Florida black bear is a subspecies. This sequence ensures accurate identification of the taxonomic rank by confirming the overarching species and genus to which the subspecies belongs.

retrieved_passages:
Florida black bear
The Florida black bear ("Ursus americanus floridanus") is a subspecies of the American black bear that has historically ranged throughout most of Florida and southern portions of Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi. The large black-furred bears live mainly in forested areas and have seen recent habitat reduction throughout the state.

Ussuri black bear
The Ussuri black bear ("Ursus thibetanus ussuricus"), also known as the Manchurian black bear, is a large subspecies of the Asian black bear native to the Far East, including the Korean Peninsula.

Baluchistan bear
The Baluchistan bear, also called the Pakistan black bear ("Ursus thibetanus gedrosianus") is a subspecies of the Asian black bear found in the Baluchistan Mountains of southern Pakistan and Iran. It has an unusually thin coat for an Asian black bear, but this is because it is found in a warmer climate than most of the other subspecies, which are found in the much colder Himalayan Mountains. It is also more frugivorous than the other subspecies, and it loves to eat figs and bananas.

Newfoundland black bear
The Newfoundland black bear ("Ursus americanus hamiltoni") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear which is endemic to the island of Newfoundland in Atlantic Canada. The Newfoundland black bear is generally larger than its mainland relatives, ranging in size from 90 to and averaging 135 kg . It also has one of the longest hibernation periods of any bear in North America.

Ursus americanus carlottae
The Haida Gwaii black bear ("Ursus americanus carlottae") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear. The most significant morphological differences are its large size, massive cranium, and large molars. This subspecies is endemic to the Haida Gwaii (Queen Charlotte Islands) and is considered a "keystone species" because of the bears transportation of salmon remains into surrounding forests of Haida Gwaii.

Cinnamon bear
The cinnamon bear ("Ursus americanus cinnamomum") is both a color phase and subspecies of the American black bear, native to central and western areas of the United States and Canada. Established populations are found in Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, Idaho, Montana, Washington, Manitoba Minnesota, Wisconsin, Wyoming, California, Alberta, and British Columbia. They also have been seen in Pennsylvania and New York. The most striking difference between a cinnamon bear and any other black bear is its brown or red-brown fur, reminiscent of cinnamon. The subspecies was given the designation because the lighter color phase is more common there than in other areas.

Japanese black bear
The Japanese black bear ("Ursus thibetanus japonicus") is a subspecies of the Asian black bear that lives on three main islands of Japan: Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu. There are said to be 10,000 black bears on Japan. The population of black bears on Shikoku and Kyushu may be endangered or extinct. There is a high price on bear parts in the black market, which threatens all bear populations in Japan. This particular species of bear are typically smaller with males only reaching 60-120 Kg and females only weighing about 40-100 Kg. Their body length is about 120–140 cm long.

Kermode bear
The Kermode bear ("Ursus americanus kermodei"), also known as the "spirit bear" (particularly in British Columbia), is a rare subspecies of the American black bear living in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada. It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia. It is noted for about one-tenth of its population having white or cream-coloured coats like polar bears. This colour is due to a double recessive gene unique in the subspecies. They are not albinos and not any more related to polar bears or the "blonde" brown bears of Alaska's "ABC Islands" than other members of their species. Sometimes, a mother black bear can have a white cub.
thoughts: The Florida black bear, also known as "Ursus americanus floridanus," is a subspecies of the American black bear. It historically ranged throughout most of Florida and southern portions of Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi. The large black-furred bears live mainly in forested areas and have seen recent habitat reduction throughout the state.

Genus: Ursus
Species: americanus floridanus

question: What is the genus and species of the bear in which the Florida black bear is a subspecies of?

nodes.instruction: Identify the scientific name of the Florida black bear subspecies.

graph.explanation: The execution graph consists of two main steps: first, retrieving information about the Florida black bear to identify its scientific name, which is Ursus americanus floridanus. This involves determining what the full species name is for the subspecies' grouping. The second step involves taking that scientific name and understanding its taxonomic classification to extract the genus and full species, which would be Ursus americanus for the subspecies Ursus americanus floridanus, showing Ursus as genus and americanus as species.

Ussuri black bear

Cinnamon bear
The cinnamon bear ("Ursus americanus cinnamomum") is both a color phase and subspecies of the American black bear, native to central and western areas of the United States and Canada. Established populations are found in Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, Idaho, Montana, Washington, Manitoba Minnesota, Wisconsin, Wyoming, California, Alberta, and British Columbia. They also have been seen in Pennsylvania and New York. The most striking difference between a cinnamon bear and any other black bear is its brown or red-brown fur, reminiscent of cinnamon. The subspecies was given the designation because the lighter color phase is more common there than in other areas.

Black Bear Creek
Black Bear Creek is a 116 mi creek in northern Oklahoma. Black Bear Creek drains an area of 538 sqmi in Garfield County, Noble County and Pawnee County, Oklahoma. It takes on a red color from the red clay of this area. The creek gets its name from the black bear. Though the area is outside of the range of the black bear, sightings have been rumored.

Ursus americanus carlottae
The Haida Gwaii black bear ("Ursus americanus carlottae") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear. The most significant morphological differences are its large size, massive cranium, and large molars. This subspecies is endemic to the Haida Gwaii (Queen Charlotte Islands) and is considered a "keystone species" because of the bears transportation of salmon remains into surrounding forests of Haida Gwaii.

Pimelea
Pimelea (often seen spelled "Pimelia", which is the name of a genus of beetles) is a genus of plants belonging to the family Thymelaeaceae. There are about 80 species in the genus, which is native to Australia and New Zealand. Many of the species are poisonous to cattle and horses.

List of Utricularia species
There are around 233 species in the genus "Utricularia", belonging to the Bladderwort family (Lentibulariaceae). It is the largest genus of carnivorous plants and has a worldwide distribution, being absent only from Antarctica and the oceanic islands. This genus was considered to have 250 species until Peter Taylor reduced the number to 214 in his exhaustive study, "The genus Utricularia - a taxonomic monograph", published by HMSO (1989). Taylor's classification is generally accepted, though his division of the genus in two subgenera was soon seen as obsolete. Molecular genetic studies have mostly confirmed Taylor's sections with some modifications (Jobson et al., 2003), but reinstalled the division of the genus in three subgenera. This list follows the subgeneric classification "sensu" Müller & Borsch (2005), updated with new information in Müller et al. (2006).

retrieved_passages:
Can You Ever Forgive Me? (film)
Can You Ever Forgive Me? is an upcoming biographical comedy-drama film directed by Marielle Heller, written by Nicole Holofcener and Jeff Whitty, based on Lee Israel's memoir of the same name and starring Melissa McCarthy.

My Heidelberg, I Can Not Forget You
My Heidelberg, I Can Not Forget You (German: Mein Heidelberg, ich kann Dich nicht vergessen) is a 1927 German silent film directed by James Bauer and starring Dorothea Wieck, and Hans Adalbert Schlettow.

(You Can Still) Rock in America
"(You Can Still) Rock in America" is a rock anthem written by Jack Blades and Brad Gillis, and the first single released from Night Ranger's 1983 album "Midnight Madness". Former Deep Purple and Black Sabbath singer Glenn Hughes contribute backing vocals on the song.

Pottery fracture
Pottery fracture results from stress within a ceramic body due to thermal expansion and contraction, shrinkage, and other forces. Poor drying or uneven compression and alignment of particles can result in low strength. Cracking may appear in greenware as well as each stage of the firing including bisque ware and glazed ware.

Please Take Care of My Refrigerator
Please Take Care of My Refrigerator () is a 2014 South Korean cooking-variety program starring by many chefs and celebrity guests. It airs on JTBC on Mondays at 21:30 (KST) beginning November 17, 2014.

Lost Someone
"Lost Someone" is a song recorded by James Brown in 1961. It was written by Brown and Famous Flames members Bobby Byrd and Baby Lloyd Stallworth. Like "Please, Please, Please" before it, the song's lyrics combine a lament for lost love with a plea for forgiveness. The single was a #2 R&B hit and reached #48 on the pop chart. According to Brown, "Lost Someone" is based on the chord changes of the Conway Twitty song "It's Only Make Believe".

Publication bias
Publication bias is a type of bias that occurs in published academic research. It occurs when the outcome of an experiment or research study influences the decision whether to publish or otherwise distribute it. Publication bias matters because literature reviews regarding support for a hypothesis can be biased if the original literature is contaminated by publication bias. Publishing only results that show a significant finding disturbs the balance of findings.

Never Let Me Go (Johnny Ace song)
"Never Let Me Go" is a blues ballad song by American R&B/blues singer Johnny Ace, written by Joseph Scott and released in 1954 under Duke Records. The song is featured on the albums "My Songs" and "Memorial". "Never Let Me Go" was one of his eighth consecutive top ten R&B hits in a row, including "My Song", "Cross My Heart," "Please Forgive Me," "The Clock," "Pledging My Love," "Saving My Love for You," and "Anymore". The song was R&B hit and peaked to No. 9 in October 1954 on "Billboards" Rhythm & Blues Records chart.
thoughts: The Florida black bear (Ursus americanus floridanus) is a subspecies of the American black bear (Ursus americanus). It is classified as a large mammal in the family Ursidae and is native to the state of Florida in the United States. The Florida black bear is known for its distinctive black fur and can be found in various habitats including forests, swamps, and marshes. It is considered a threatened species due to habitat loss and human encroachment.

Genus: Ursus
Species: americanus floridanus

Latrodectus variolus, the northern black widow spider or northern widow, is a medically important spider species of the genus "Latrodectus" in the family Theridiidae. Kermode bear
The Kermode bear ("Ursus americanus kermodei"), also known as the "spirit bear" (particularly in British Columbia), is a rare subspecies of the American black bear living in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada. It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia. It is noted for about one-tenth of its population having white or cream-coloured coats like polar bears. This colour is due to a double recessive gene unique in the subspecies. They are not albinos and not any more related to polar bears or the "blonde" brown bears of Alaska's "ABC Islands" than other members of their species. Sometimes, a mother black bear can have a white cub.

Ussuri black bear
The Ussuri black bear ("Ursus thibetanus ussuricus"), also known as the Manchurian black bear, is a large subspecies of the Asian black bear native to the Far East, including the Korean Peninsula.

Black Bear Creek
Black Bear Creek is a 116 mi creek in northern Oklahoma. Black Bear Creek drains an area of 538 sqmi in Garfield County, Noble County and Pawnee County, Oklahoma. It takes on a red color from the red clay of this area. The creek gets its name from the black bear. Though the area is outside of the range of the black bear, sightings have been rumored.

Newfoundland black bear
The Newfoundland black bear ("Ursus americanus hamiltoni") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear which is endemic to the island of Newfoundland in Atlantic Canada. The Newfoundland black bear is generally larger than its mainland relatives, ranging in size from 90 to and averaging 135 kg . It also has one of the longest hibernation periods of any bear in North America.

American black bear
The American black bear ("Ursus americanus") is a medium-sized bear native to North America.

Baluchistan bear
The Baluchistan bear, also called the Pakistan black bear ("Ursus thibetanus gedrosianus") is a subspecies of the Asian black bear found in the Baluchistan Mountains of southern Pakistan and Iran. It has an unusually thin coat for an Asian black bear, but this is because it is found in a warmer climate than most of the other subspecies, which are found in the much colder Himalayan Mountains. It is also more frugivorous than the other subspecies, and it loves to eat figs and bananas.
thoughts: The Florida black bear, also known as "Ursus americanus floridanus," is a subspecies of the American black bear that historically ranged throughout most of Florida and southern portions of Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi. These large black-furred bears mainly inhabit forested areas and have seen recent habitat reduction throughout the state. They are a distinct subspecies with their own unique characteristics and habitat.

Kingdom: Animalia
Phylum: Chordata
Class: Mammalia
Order: Carnivora
Family: Ursidae
Genus: Ursus
Species: Ursus americanus
Subspecies: Ursus americanus floridanus
The Florida black bear belongs to the species "Ursus americanus" and the subspecies "floridanus."

question: What is the genus and species of the bear in which the Florida black bear is a subspecies of?

nodes.instruction: Determine the subspecies classification of the Florida black bear.
Retrieve the bear species that the Florida black bear subspecies belongs to.
Find the genus of the species identified in the previous step.
Combine the genus and species information to provide the complete scientific name of the bear species of which the Florida black bear is a subspecies.

graph.explanation: To find the genus and species of the bear in which the Florida black bear is a subspecies, we first determine its subspecies classification. This leads to identifying the species that the subspecies belongs to. Once the species is known, we can retrieve the genus. Finally, combining both the genus and species gives us the complete scientific name of the bear species.

retrieved_passages:
Florida black bear
The Florida black bear ("Ursus americanus floridanus") is a subspecies of the American black bear that has historically ranged throughout most of Florida and southern portions of Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi. The large black-furred bears live mainly in forested areas and have seen recent habitat reduction throughout the state.

Japanese black bear
The Japanese black bear ("Ursus thibetanus japonicus") is a subspecies of the Asian black bear that lives on three main islands of Japan: Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu. There are said to be 10,000 black bears on Japan. The population of black bears on Shikoku and Kyushu may be endangered or extinct. There is a high price on bear parts in the black market, which threatens all bear populations in Japan. This particular species of bear are typically smaller with males only reaching 60-120 Kg and females only weighing about 40-100 Kg. Their body length is about 120–140 cm long.

Ussuri black bear
The Ussuri black bear ("Ursus thibetanus ussuricus"), also known as the Manchurian black bear, is a large subspecies of the Asian black bear native to the Far East, including the Korean Peninsula.

Ursus americanus carlottae
The Haida Gwaii black bear ("Ursus americanus carlottae") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear. The most significant morphological differences are its large size, massive cranium, and large molars. This subspecies is endemic to the Haida Gwaii (Queen Charlotte Islands) and is considered a "keystone species" because of the bears transportation of salmon remains into surrounding forests of Haida Gwaii.

Kermode bear
The Kermode bear ("Ursus americanus kermodei"), also known as the "spirit bear" (particularly in British Columbia), is a rare subspecies of the American black bear living in the Central and North Coast regions of British Columbia, Canada. It is the official provincial mammal of British Columbia. It is noted for about one-tenth of its population having white or cream-coloured coats like polar bears. This colour is due to a double recessive gene unique in the subspecies. They are not albinos and not any more related to polar bears or the "blonde" brown bears of Alaska's "ABC Islands" than other members of their species. Sometimes, a mother black bear can have a white cub.

Baluchistan bear
The Baluchistan bear, also called the Pakistan black bear ("Ursus thibetanus gedrosianus") is a subspecies of the Asian black bear found in the Baluchistan Mountains of southern Pakistan and Iran. It has an unusually thin coat for an Asian black bear, but this is because it is found in a warmer climate than most of the other subspecies, which are found in the much colder Himalayan Mountains. It is also more frugivorous than the other subspecies, and it loves to eat figs and bananas.

Newfoundland black bear
The Newfoundland black bear ("Ursus americanus hamiltoni") is a morphologically distinct subspecies of the American black bear which is endemic to the island of Newfoundland in Atlantic Canada. The Newfoundland black bear is generally larger than its mainland relatives, ranging in size from 90 to and averaging 135 kg . It also has one of the longest hibernation periods of any bear in North America.

Cinnamon bear
The cinnamon bear ("Ursus americanus cinnamomum") is both a color phase and subspecies of the American black bear, native to central and western areas of the United States and Canada. Established populations are found in Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, Idaho, Montana, Washington, Manitoba Minnesota, Wisconsin, Wyoming, California, Alberta, and British Columbia. They also have been seen in Pennsylvania and New York. The most striking difference between a cinnamon bear and any other black bear is its brown or red-brown fur, reminiscent of cinnamon. The subspecies was given the designation because the lighter color phase is more common there than in other areas.

American black bear
The American black bear ("Ursus americanus") is a medium-sized bear native to North America.

Latrodectus variolus
Latrodectus variolus, the northern black widow spider or northern widow, is a medically important spider species of the genus "Latrodectus" in the family Theridiidae. The population is closely related to the southern black widow, "Latrodectus mactans", and the western black widow, "Latrodectus hesperus", of the genus.
thoughts: The Florida black bear is classified as "Ursus americanus floridanus", a subspecies of the American black bear.
The Florida black bear subspecies belongs to the American black bear species (Ursus americanus).

The genus of the species identified in the previous step are as follows:
- Japanese black bear ("Ursus thibetanus japonicus")
- Haida Gwaii black bear ("Ursus americanus carlottae")
- Kermode bear ("Ursus americanus kermodei")
- American black bear ("Ursus americanus")
- Newfoundland black bear ("Ursus americanus hamiltoni")
- Florida black bear ("Ursus americanus floridanus")
- Ussuri black bear ("Ursus thibetanus ussuricus")
- Northern black widow spider ("Latrodectus variolus")
The complete scientific name of the bear species of which the Florida black bear is a subspecies is Ursus americanus.

Rhodostemonodaphne
Rhodostemonodaphne is a genus of flowering plants in the family Lauraceae. It is a neotropical genus consisting of approximately 41 species occurring in Central America and northern South America. This genus has many species that are valued for timber. The classification of the genus is unclear since the species in the genus fall into a well-supported but unresolved clade that also includes species with unisexual flowers currently placed in the genera "Endlicheria" and part of "Ocotea".

Newfoundland black bear

It also has one of the longest hibernation periods of any bear in North America.

retrieved_passages:
Can You Ever Forgive Me? (film)
Can You Ever Forgive Me? is an upcoming biographical comedy-drama film directed by Marielle Heller, written by Nicole Holofcener and Jeff Whitty, based on Lee Israel's memoir of the same name and starring Melissa McCarthy.

My Heidelberg, I Can Not Forget You
My Heidelberg, I Can Not Forget You (German: Mein Heidelberg, ich kann Dich nicht vergessen) is a 1927 German silent film directed by James Bauer and starring Dorothea Wieck, and Hans Adalbert Schlettow.

(You Can Still) Rock in America
"(You Can Still) Rock in America" is a rock anthem written by Jack Blades and Brad Gillis, and the first single released from Night Ranger's 1983 album "Midnight Madness". Former Deep Purple and Black Sabbath singer Glenn Hughes contribute backing vocals on the song.

Pottery fracture
Pottery fracture results from stress within a ceramic body due to thermal expansion and contraction, shrinkage, and other forces. Poor drying or uneven compression and alignment of particles can result in low strength. Cracking may appear in greenware as well as each stage of the firing including bisque ware and glazed ware.

Please Take Care of My Refrigerator
Please Take Care of My Refrigerator () is a 2014 South Korean cooking-variety program starring by many chefs and celebrity guests. It airs on JTBC on Mondays at 21:30 (KST) beginning November 17, 2014.

Lost Someone
"Lost Someone" is a song recorded by James Brown in 1961. It was written by Brown and Famous Flames members Bobby Byrd and Baby Lloyd Stallworth. Like "Please, Please, Please" before it, the song's lyrics combine a lament for lost love with a plea for forgiveness. The single was a #2 R&B hit and reached #48 on the pop chart. According to Brown, "Lost Someone" is based on the chord changes of the Conway Twitty song "It's Only Make Believe".

Publication bias
Publication bias is a type of bias that occurs in published academic research. It occurs when the outcome of an experiment or research study influences the decision whether to publish or otherwise distribute it. Publication bias matters because literature reviews regarding support for a hypothesis can be biased if the original literature is contaminated by publication bias. Publishing only results that show a significant finding disturbs the balance of findings.

Never Let Me Go (Johnny Ace song)
"Never Let Me Go" is a blues ballad song by American R&B/blues singer Johnny Ace, written by Joseph Scott and released in 1954 under Duke Records. The song is featured on the albums "My Songs" and "Memorial". "Never Let Me Go" was one of his eighth consecutive top ten R&B hits in a row, including "My Song", "Cross My Heart," "Please Forgive Me," "The Clock," "Pledging My Love," "Saving My Love for You," and "Anymore". The song was R&B hit and peaked to No. 9 in October 1954 on "Billboards" Rhythm & Blues Records chart.
thoughts: The Florida black bear, also known as the Ursus americanus floridanus, is a subspecies of the American black bear. It is classified under the genus Ursus and the species americanus. The Florida black bear is a large mammal native to Florida and is currently listed as a threatened species due to habitat loss and human-wildlife conflict.
The genus of the Florida black bear is Ursus and the species is americanus.
